awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description: Multiferroics are promising materials because of their potential applications for spintronics (data storage, etc.) and novel multifunctional devices. Devices based on these materials have many important features, such as high speed, low power consumption, and multi-functionality, and could facilitate device miniaturization impacting daily life. The project will contribute to the understanding of the new physical phenomena and fundamental science in nanostructured multiferroics.  The project involves underrepresented graduate and undergraduate students (e.g., Hispanics and/or women). The PI designs new courses, disseminates new findings through presentations at conferences and publication in scientific journals, and organizes a workshop on multifunctional nanomaterials involving the participation of graduate students. 

Technical description: The research goal of this project is to understand the magnetodielectric coupling in nanostructured multiferroics, which is important for the realization of novel spintronic and multifunctional devices. The mechanisms and dynamics of magnetodielectric coupling and the origin of the fundamental excitation in multiferroics are not yet well understood. The project aims at a comprehensive understanding of mechanisms and dynamics of magnetodielectric coupling in nanostructured multiferroics, the factors that affect it, and the approaches to control and enhance the properties. These nanostructures include nanograin polycrystalline single phase thin films, nanoscale epitaxial thin films, and artificially engineered multiferroics using ferromagnetic/ ferroelectric epitaxial heterostructures. The specific tasks are to (i) study the magnetodielectric coupling in nanocomposite and polycrystalline thin films; (ii) explore the effect of strain, reduced dimensionality, and interface effect on magnetodielectric coupling in epitaxial thin films and artificially engineered ferroelectric/ferromagnetic multilayer heterostructures; (iii) examine the effect of temperature, frequency, and electromagnetic field on magnetodielectric coupling.  These nanostructured multiferroics are grown by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) and molecular beam epitaxy (MBE), and analyzed by several state-of-the-art characterization techniques.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

The research goal of this project was to understand the magnetodielectric coupling in nanostructured multiferroics and study the origin of magnetic ordering in III-nitrided based magnetic semiconductors. Understanding of these effects are important for the realization of novel spintronic and multifunctional devices. The educational goal of this proposal is to enhance the participation of underrepresented minority groups in in science and engineering.  The outcome of this project can be evaluated based on the following five aspects, such as scientific accomplishment, research facility development, human resource development, curriculum development, and educational outreach, as described below:

Intellectual Merits:

 1.Research Accomplishments:

During the course of the execution of the project, various multiferroics and III-nitrides based magnetic semiconductors were investigated. The analysis of their structural, microstructural, electrical, optical, magnetic, magetodielectric properties as a function of temperature, frequency, magnetic field, and electric field revealed better understanding of magnetoelectric and magnetodielectric coupling and origin of magnetic ordering. The results of our research were published in 14 (fourteen) peer reviewed scientific research articles and presented in various scientific conferences; including eight invited talks.

Broder Impact:

 2.Research Facility Development:

The PI already designed and set up a pulsed laser deposition (PLD) system for the growth of oxide thin films and revived a molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) technique for the growth of nitride thin films. These techniques helped the project to study oxide and nitride thin films and heterostructures. The PI also developed a magnetoelectric (ME) measurement system and high temperature electrical (I-V) measurement system. These infrastructures will have a significant impact on the capability of the institute to carry out future research and development. The PI also acquired a high temperature furnace that could be used for high temperature sintering. These systems are now operational and extensively used for the growth of multifunctional oxide thin films by graduates and undergraduate students for their research. 

3. Human Resource Development:

The project involves and supported four graduate students (3- Hispanic minority) and one undergraduate student (female Hispanic) to carry out the research and to complete their degree. PhD students are given the opportunity to learn state-of-the-art thin film growth techniques and also to participate in different national and international conferences to present their research. The knowledge and experience gained by students will immensely help them to choose a career in industry or academia.  The graduate students are given the opportunity to attend premier conferences in the field of our research.

4. Curriculum Development:

The PI developed and taught a special course on “FISI 8992: Thin film Science & Technology” to graduate students at the University of Puerto Rico for several semesters.

5.Educational Outreach Activities:

 The PI organized and chaired two workshops “Workshop on Multifunctional Nanomaterials” (Jan 14-16, and Dec 15-18, 2015) in San Juan PR. There were about 100 participants and out of which 60% were University of Puerto Rico graduate students and faculties. The participants in the workshop were three times more than expected attendance.

The results from the project were disseminated to communities by participating NanoDays at different shopping malls in Puerto Rico by graduate students. The graduate students attended different premier conferences (MRS, MMM) to present our research work and submitted their theses. The PI also delivered several invited talks at different universities. We are also publishing our research work in different scientific journals and theses.  

 

 


Last Modified: 06/19/2024
Modified by: Ratnakar Palai
